thread.title: Report: VW scandal could cost more than BP's Deepwater Horizon spill
thread.title_full: Report: VW scandal could cost more than BP's Deepwater Horizon spill - CNET

author: Chris Paukert
title: Report: VW scandal could cost more than BP's Deepwater Horizon spill
text:
Antuan Goodwin/CNET If a major financial services company's estimate is accurate, Volkswagen's TDI diesel emissions scandal could cost the automaker up to $86 billion dollars.
According to CNNMoney , Credit Suisse analysts told investors that they believe other estimates aren't adequately taking into consideration secondary costs and cascading fallout from the scandal: "The market does not appear to be discounting negative knock-on effects," they wrote in a statement.
That $86-billion figure is exponentially more than other previous cost estimates, and if Credit Suisse is right, the $7.3 billion in funds VW set aside after the scandal broke in September will be woefully inadequate.
VW, the world's largest automaker by volume, has been in a tailspin since it was announced that the company deliberately programmed its nearly 500,000 diesel cars to circumvent EPA emissions standards. The quandary involving the so-called "defeat device," which allows cars to pollute up to 40 times the EPA's legal limit, has subsequently widened to include nearly 11 million cars globally.
Credit Suisse's "worst case scenario" argues VW's tab could skyrocket because of uncertain costs associated with the recall of these polluting TDI diesel models, which could suffer reduced performance after a fix brings them into emissions compliance . The financial company believes that the German automaker may have to reimburse customers for related damages to the tune of $33 billion dollars.
Credit Suisse's best-case-scenario number of about $26 billion is still well over triple VW's estimate -- in fact, that's more cash than the automaker has on hand altogether.
In the investor note referenced by CNNMoney, Credit Suisse also warned that VW's shares need to fall about 20% to about $92.60 a share to reflect their true value -- and that's on top of the 35% hit that its stock has already taken since the scandal first came to light. Indeed, as of this writing, VW's stock has plummeted to $92.16.
If Credit Suisse's high-end estimate is accurate, VW's total cost could easily eclipse the clean-up cost of an altogether different petrochemical emissions nightmare -- BP's 2010 Deepwater Horizon oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
